title: John Hamilton (congressman)
text:
John Hamilton (November 25, 1754August 22, 1837) was a member of the <a href="United%20States%20House%20of%20Representatives">United States House of Representatives</a> from <a href="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a>.
Biography.
John Hamilton was born in <a href="York%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">York County</a> (in the part that is now <a href="Adams%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">Adams County</a>) in the <a href="Province%20of%20Pennsylvania">Province of Pennsylvania</a>. He moved to <a href="Washington%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">Washington County, Pennsylvania</a>, in 1783. He was commissioned lieutenant colonel of militia in 1786 and brigadier general in 1800. He was major general of the Fourteenth Division of Militia of Washington and <a href="Greene%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">Greene</a> Counties in 1807. He was appointed high <a href="sheriff">sheriff</a> of Washington County by <a href="List%20of%20Governors%20of%20Pennsylvania">Governor</a> <a href="Thomas%20Mifflin">Thomas Mifflin</a> in 1793 and served until November 1, 1796. He was a member of the <a href="Pennsylvania%20State%20Senate">Pennsylvania State Senate</a> from 1796 to 1805 and an associate judge of Washington County from 1802 to 1805. He was a member of the first board of trustees of Jefferson college (now <a href="Washington%20%26amp%3B%20Jefferson%20College">Washington & Jefferson College</a>) in Washington, Pennsylvania, serving from 1802 to 1831.
Hamilton was elected as a Republican to the <a href="9th%20United%20States%20Congress">Ninth</a> Congress. He was again appointed associate judge of Washington County on May 31, 1820, and served until his death at his home near <a href="Ginger%20Hill%2C%20Pennsylvania">Ginger Hill, Pennsylvania</a>. Interment in Mingo Cemetery, near <a href="Monongahela%2C%20Pennsylvania">Monongahela, Pennsylvania</a>.
